page.title: 04SALT MARSHES, WELLS, NORFOLK
page.content: The salt marshes lie to the East of Wells and stretch for about 5 km towards Weybourne. A line deciduous trees separates the farmland from the marsh with its distinctive vegetation lining the muddy and sandy creeks. Between the trees and the sea the marsh vegetation consists of various grasses, Sea Aster, Sea Blite, Sea Plantain, Sea Pink and a small green planed Samphire. This is a fleshy segmented plant which is edible and is gathered and sold commercially. Another harvest of the sands beyond the marsh is the cockle, most famous of which is the "Stukey Blue". Shore crabs are plentiful in this area; they scavenge for decaying material produced in the salt marsh.These and other creatures provide food for thousands of waders and wild fowl.
